answers.answer: There actually are some theories out there about the role of inflammation in psychiatric disorders as well as other disorders, but we really don't know very much about the whole process yet.  There's also an oxidative stress theory, and there's some evidence that n-acetylcysteine helps with bipolar depression.  N-acetylcysteine is a precursor to glutathione, which is an antioxidant (NAC is actually used as a drug for acute acetaminophen/paracetamol poisoning and for certain lung disorders, but it can be obtained OTC).  Don't bother with glutathione itself, though.  I believe it gets broken down in the liver upon absorption and doesn't make it to the rest of the body.My understanding with curcumin is that it has extremely sh*tty bioavailability, and is thus fairly useless.  Psycheducation.org has an interesting section on supplements with some evidence cited from decent research on this stuff.
